title: Coronation Street's Antony Cotton heads to Santorini to see the sunset
text:
99 shares 1
View
comments
I had always wanted to visit the Greek island of Santorini – mainly to see the sunset everybody raves about.
I arranged a seven-night stay during a break from filming Coronation Street . My partner Peter and I had three days at the Esperas hotel in Oia and four days at the Aigialos in Fira.
It turned out to be an absolutely brilliant week.
Corrie star Antony Cotton spent plenty of time admiring sunsets when he wasn't exploring the island
We were primarily looking for complete relaxation. We wanted to lie by the pool and enjoy the sunshine, but we were also keen to see something of the island. We hired a car so we were able to do a bit of wandering around to enjoy the scenery.
Santorini has a long and fascinating history. It is linked to the Atlantis legend, and some people believe it was a huge volcanic explosion on Santorini that caused the biblical plagues which afflicted Egypt, and also caused the sea to part.
The island is relatively small but has an airport with a variety of connections to the UK.

Thomas Cook tells holidaymakers they WON’T get a refund for... 99 shares First things first: the sunset. It was more beautiful than you can possibly imagine. The Esperas hotel is in a row of traditional houses and, with its huge balcony, our room offered the perfect sunset vantage point. Every evening we simply wandered outside to enjoy the most extraordinary spectacle.
The small town of Oia is built into the side of what was a volcano. From our hotel it was a steep walk down a lot of steps to the sea. There are few organised activities and not a huge amount of nightlife – but this suited us fine.
The busiest islanders are the donkeys that take tourists up and down from the harbour. It’s hard work for them in the heat of the day.
Antony and his partner, Peter, spent seven nights in Santorini as he took a break from filming
Another highlight of the holiday was the food. We ate out in a couple of places in Fira and Oia. We had an excellent meal at Fino restaurant in Oia, and I can recommend an amazing bar called Hasapiko, also in Oia.
The bar is in what used to be the village butcher’s, and it had what looked like ancient blood-flecked meat-hooks driven into the brickwork by the front door. Hasapiko was a great place – it’s where all the hip young kids went.
We had wonderful seafood at a seafront restaurant called Dimitris, and I had an amazing fillet steak at the Aigialos hotel. In fact both the hotels we stayed at were first-class.
GETTING THERE Sunvil Holidays ( sunvil.co.uk/greece , 020 8758 4758) offers a two-centre, seven-night stay on Santorini from £1,169pp.
The price includes return flights from Gatwick or Manchester, transfers, four nights’ B&B at the Esperas Traditional Houses and three nights’ bed and breakfast at the Aigialos Traditional Settlement Hotel.
If you’re looking for a great holiday, I don’t think you could find anywhere more beautiful than the island of Santorini. We loved the peace and quiet, and the local people were so kind and friendly.
And then there are those fabled sunsets. I’ll never forget them. The hotel sold lovely champagne and, each night, we would have a little glass on the terrace as we watched the sun go down.
I’ve enjoyed sunsets in plenty of places, but Santorini’s somehow seemed different. It was so dramatic: one moment the sun was there and everything was light, and then, within what seemed like half a second, it was gone… and the nightlife could begin.
Perfect!
Greece is having a tough time at the moment with all of its financial problems, and holidaymakers have understandably been worried about going there.
But just because the country is having economic difficulties, it doesn’t mean we shouldn’t visit. In fact, it’s a reason why we should go, to help them get back on their feet.
Places such as Santorini depend heavily on tourism. Now’s the time to visit.
